qMRLab

  • qMRLab Introduction
  • View page source

qMRLab Introduction¶

qMRLab is an open-source software for quantitative MR image analysis. The main goal is to provide the community with an intuitive tool for data fitting, plotting, simulation and protocol optimization for a myriad of different quantitative models. The modularity of the implementation makes it easy to add any additional modules and we encourage everyone to contribute their favorite recipe for qMR!

qMRLab is a fork from the initial project qMTLab. For a quick introduction to qMTLab functionnalities, see the qMTLab presentation e-poster or alternatively you can view it on YouTube.

Data simulator¶

The simulation interface allows end users to easily simulate qMR data and evaluate how well these models perform under known parameters input, determine the most appropriate acquisition protocol and evaluate how fitting constraints impact the results.

Data fitting and visualization¶

The data fitting provides a simple interface to import real-world qMR data, fit them using the selected fitting procedure, and visualize the resulting parameter maps. More advanced users could also use the command line tools used in the background by the GUI to include data fitting in their analysis scripts.

Methods available¶

Diffusion¶

  • charmed: Composite Hindered and Restricted Model for Diffusion
  • dti: Diffusion Tensor Imaging
  • NODDI: Neurite Orientation Dispersion and Density Imaging

FieldMaps¶

  • B0_DEM map : Dual Echo Method for B0 mapping
  • B1_DAM map: Double-Angle Method for B1+ mapping

Magnetization_transfer¶

  • MTSAT : Correction of Magnetization transfer for RF inhomogeneities and T1
  • qmt_bssfp : qMT using Balanced Steady State Free Precession acquisition
  • qmt_sirfse: qMT using Inversion Recovery Fast Spin Echo acquisition
  • qmt_spgr: quantitative Magnetizatoion Transfer (qMT) using Spoiled Gradient Echo (or FLASH)

Noise¶

  • noise_level : Noise histogram fitting within a noise mask

T1_relaxometry¶

  • inversion_recovery: Compute a T1 map using Inversion Recovery data
  • vfa_t1: Compute a T1 map using Variable Flip Angle

T2_relaxometry¶

  • mwf : Myelin Water Fraction from Multi-Exponential T2w data

UnderDevelopment¶

  • Name your Model
  • mtv : Macromolecular Tissue Volume

Getting started¶

Dependencies¶

  • MATLAB_R2014b or later (octave compatibility currently being implemented)

Installing qMRlab¶

Zip Download Instructions¶

The latest stable version of qMRLab can be downloaded freely here.

  • Extract the downloaded file to the directory you want to install qMRLab.
  • Open MATLAB, got to the qMRLab folder and run startup.
  • To start a qMRLab session, run qMRLab.

Command-Line Instructions¶

If you have git available on a command-line interface (e.g. Terminal on Mac OSX, Git Shell on Windows), the installation can be completed using a few quick commands.

  • In the command-line interface, navigate (cd) to the directory that you want to install qMRLab

  • Clone the directory:

    git clone https://github.com/neuropoly/qMRLab.git

  • Open MATLAB, got to the qMRLab folder and run startup.

  • To start a qMRLab session, run qMRLab.

Citation¶

If you use qMRLab in you work, please cite:

Cabana, J.-F., Gu, Y., Boudreau, M., Levesque, I. R., Atchia, Y., Sled, J. G., Narayanan, S., Arnold, D. L., Pike, G. B., Cohen-Adad, J., Duval, T., Vuong, M.-T. and Stikov, N. (2016), Quantitative magnetization transfer imaging made easy with qMTLab: Software for data simulation, analysis, and visualization. Concepts Magn. Reson.. doi: 10.1002/cmr.a.21357

Please also cite the reference for the particular module you are using (specified in each model’s page).
